results.title: The Canadian shield: Saguenay region
results.creator_credit: Werner Aellen, Rene Jodoin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film focuses on the Saguenay area of Quebvec as seen from a helicopter. From this vantage point, the size and resources - wood, water, arable land and mineral-bearing rock are easy to see. At closer range the film shows the industries and agricultural development of the region.

results.title: Canada: landform regions
results.creator_credit: Eugene Boyko, Frank Spiller, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A view of Canada from a helicopter, showing the nature and extent of the various landform regions. We see the immense spread of forest, rock and lakeland that makes up the Canadian Shield, the plains and lowlands where the industry of man is more evident, and finally, the coastal mountain ranges of the west, north and east. The influence of the geological character of the land on what people do and where they live is illustrated in closer views of industry, urban and rural, across the country. Photography: Eugene Boyko. Award: Sydney
results.creator_credit_for_label: Eugene Boyko, Frank Spiller, Sidney Goldsmith and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Camel who took a walk
results.brief_description: From the book written by Jack Tworkov, illustrated by Roger Duvoisin, this children’s film tells the story of a camel and what “did not” happen to him as he set out for his morning walk. Uses the pictures and text from the book. Suitable for pre-school level.

results.title: A Calendar of dreamings: Aboriginal artists of Central Australia
results.brief_description: This film depicts the mythology of First Nations people in the western McDonald Range area of Central Australia with specific reference to three tribal groups. It deals with ‘water dreaming’ as well as various myths and legends related to the present situation. The film incorporates approximately 44 paintings by Central Australia First Nations people using an ancient technique known as sand painting. A study of the meanings of the symbols and signs used in some paintings. Legends of the Dreamtime are passed down to the younger member by their elders in ritual ceremonies. Narrated by John Bell, edited by Phil Noyce.

results.title: Calculated risk
results.creator_credit: Julian Sprio, James Carr, British Petroleum and World Wide
results.brief_description: The story of the search for oil in a Middle East sheikhdom. This “calculated risk” involved ten years of planning and work, and an investment of some 25 million pounds. Shows how, in the case of the Umm Shaif underwater oilfield at Abu Dhabi on the Arabian Gulf, this immense engineering project culminated in the departure of tankers for Europe with the first cargoes of crude oil.

results.title: Bush policemen
results.creator_credit: Lee Robinson, Stanley Hawes and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: The bush policeman’s beat, in the vast inland of Australia, takes him through strange and sometimes un-mapped places, to preserve law and order on the fringes of civilization. As the Mountie is to north-west Canada, so is the bush policeman to the wild, tropical north-west of Australia.

results.title: The Use of measuring instruments: the burette
results.creator_credit: L.M. Simmons and Australian Teaching Films
results.brief_description: A demonstration of the correct use of the burette. Includes checking apparatus, rinsing, placing in stand, draining, filling, removing air bubbles, measuring a specified amount of liquid, emptying, cleaning and packing up after use.

results.title: The Burden they carry
results.creator_credit: Mort Ransen, John Kemeny, Tom Daly, National Film Board of Canada and Swedish Institute for Cultural Relations
results.brief_description: Shows one of Sweden’s best known sex educators, Dr Maj-Britt Bergstrom-Wahlan, as she speaks with a class of 8 and 9 year old boys and girls. Later, she holds an informal discussion with an uninhibited group of teenagers, some from Sweden, others from the United States and Great Britain. The film concludes with a poem on the meaning of love and happiness, read by an elderly lady from an old people’s home after she has visited a public exhibition of erotic art.
